title.narrative: Provision of life-saving and gender-sensitive WASH interventions to newly displaced people

description.narrative:
Since the start of the conflict through to the recent increase in displacement, sanitation and hygiene needs have sharply increased to the point that 75% of people are in need of sanitation assistance (ACAPS, 2016). Concerns are raised about women and girls’ accessibility to WASH facilities due to the limited numbers of facilities, latrines and showers and their long distance from the dwellings/tents. Numerous Rapid Protection Assessments (RPA) carried out in Ninewa have indicated that girls and women are not comfortable using latrines because, either latrines are located far or are not designed to permit women and girls the privacy needed to address specific needs such as managing their menstrual hygiene. Other reported needs are: camps have been erected in haste to accommodate the rapid influx therefore they have not been connected to a sustainable water supply, solid waste has accumulated in and around dwellings, there are no proper mechanisms for collection, transportation and safe final disposal, no regular rehabilitation to pipes, boreholes, water taps, and a lack of accessible sanitation and hygiene for persons with physical disabilities in camp and non-camp settings
Save the Children’s (SC) proposed WASH intervention will be a first line response in accordance with the 2017 HRP for Iraq and the WASH Cluster strategy. The proposed area of intervention is Hamam Al Alil Camp 1 (HAA 1) with population of over 4000 IDPs families, 24,500 individuals, are mainly new arrivals having fled west Mosul. In HAA 1, SC is the only WASH actor and is responsible for providing all WASH services. SC will implement a full WASH package that will addresses the need of affected people in HAA 1. The key activities include procuring and prepositioning of key WASH items – chlorine, hygiene kits, solid waste bins and IEC materials. Other activities are: water trucking, water quality monitoring, operation and maintenance of latrines, showers, carryout solid waste management and conducting child-focused cleaning and hygiene awareness campaigns.
SC closely coordinates its response with NRC, Solidarity International, Oxfam, ICRC, UNICEF and department of water to ensure the needs are addressed without overlap. SC is participating actively in national WASH cluster meetings, water trucking working group and water treatment plant group. This project will be part of an SC multi-sectorial and an integrated program that includes CP, Education and NFIs – to ensure the maximum benefits for affected people. SC will implement a WASH intervention focusing on providing life-saving assistance to the most critically affected IDP children and their families in Hamam Al Alil based on cluster prioritization and fully considering cost –effectiveness.
